item.title: WTF JS explanation - string is not string
item.description: Premise ‚Äî wtfjs.com - string is not string Explanation This example mixes the two main type categories, primitives and objects. The string‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
Premise

"string" instanceof String; // false.

‚Äî wtfjs.com - string is not string

Explanation

This example mixes the two main type categories, primitives and objects. The string "foo" is not the same as new String("foo"). The first one is a Primitive value, the second is an Object.

What's the difference of a String primitive and a String object?

A string primitive is a string literal denoted by single or double quotes (e.g. 'foo' and "bar") and result from a String(...) call in a non-constructor context (without the new keyword). These primitives are automatically converted to Sting object so we can use all the methods like .toUpperCase(), .concat(), .replace() and so on on them.

This even works when we call methods directly on a string literal like this: 

"lorem ipsum".toUpperCase(); // LOREM IPSUM

Note:

  • The word literal refers to a syntax for creating data without using a constructor.
  • The word primitive refers to a non-object data.
  • JSON.parse('"foo"'), .toUpperCase(), .concat(), .replace() and other string methods are returning primitives too

In case you are wondering, a string object can be converted to a primitive with the .valueOf() method. This method is used even internally when coertion happens.

This is why:

let str_primitive = "foo";
typeof str_primitive; // "string"
str_primitive instanceof String; // false

let str_object = new String("bar");
typeof str_object; // "object"
str_object instanceof String; // true

Further reading:

  • The wrapper object - javascriptrefined.io
  • String - mozilla.org
  • Difference between string literals and string objects - stackoverflow

item.title: Enhanced object literals - ES6
item.description: In general Enhanced object literals are making our lives easier in a way that we can use a more intuitive syntax when defining our objects‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
In general Enhanced object literals are making our lives easier in a way that we can use a more intuitive syntax when defining our objects. We've got 3 new tricks to define our properties and methods:

Property Shorthand

A property shorthand means that instead of this:

// ES5 syntax
const Obj = {
    foo: foo,
    bar: bar
};

... we can just use a more simple syntax:

// ES6 syntax
const Obj = { foo, bar };

Method Properties

This is also some kind of shorthand, because instead of this:

// ES5 syntax
const Obj = {
    foo: function (a, b) {
        ...
    },
    bar: function (x, y) {
        ...
    },
};

... we can write this:

// ES6 syntax
const Obj = {
    foo(a, b) {
        ...
    },
    bar(x, y) {
        ...
    }
}

As of ES6 we can use Generator functions and Async functions too. We can use two ways of defining this kind of methods in an object:

const Obj = {
    // Generator function with named property
    fooGenerator: function* () {
        ...
    },

    // and now with the shorthand syntax
    * barGenerator() {
        ...
    },

    // this works with Async functions too
    fooAsync: async function() {
        await foo_promise;
    },

    async barAsync() {
        await bar_promise;
    }
};

const Obj

Computed property names

Another big win is the computed property name. Now instead of this:

function fn() {
    var foo = "foo";
    var ret = {};

    ret[foo] = "bar";

    return ret;
}

... we can simply use this:

function fn() {
    let foo = "foo";

    return {
        [foo]: "bar"
    };
}

What a delight! ‚òïÔ∏èüòÑ

item.title: Sorting an array of objects with pure Javascript
item.description: The basics Let's cover up in short how can we sort an Array in Vanilla Javascript. Suppose that we have a simple array of strings: ["ij‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
The basics

Let's cover up in short how can we sort an Array in Vanilla Javascript.

Suppose that we have a simple array of strings: ["ij", "cd", "kl", "ef", "gh", "ab"]

If we want to simply sort it in an ascending order we can use the Array.prototype.sort method:

["ij", "cd", "kl", "ef", "gh", "ab"].sort(); // ["ab", "cd", "ef", "gh", "ij", "kl"]

In case a reverse order is needed we can use the Array.prototype.reverse for this:

["ij", "cd", "kl", "ef", "gh", "ab"].sort().reverse(); // ["kl", "ij", "gh", "ef", "cd", "ab"]

What about numbers?

Unfortunately the simple sort orders array items as Strings. So in case of an array of numbers there is no delight by writing this:

[20, 1, 5, 12, 59, 100, 4].sort(); // [1, 100, 12, 20, 4, 5, 59]

As we can see after 1 we have 100 and not 4. Fortunately the Array.prototype.sort function is a higher-order function (which means it can receive a function as an argument) and its only argument is a comparator function.

This is the definition of the comparator function in the ECMAScript Spec:

If comparefn is not undefined, it should be a function that accepts two arguments x and y and returns a negative value if x < y, zero if x = y, or a positive value if x > y.

‚Äî Array.prototype.sort -- ecma-international.org

The easiest win for ordering the array by numbers is this:

[20, 1, 5, 12, 59, 100, 4].sort((a, b) => a - b); // [1, 4, 5, 12, 20, 59, 100]

To reverse this order just change a - b to b - a like this:

[20, 1, 5, 12, 59, 100, 4].sort((a, b) => b - a); // [100, 59, 20, 12, 5, 4, 1]

So far so good but what about objects?

No prob, bro. Just use an object property in the comparator function:

var obj = [
    { name: 'amet',  index: 5 },
    { name: 'ipsum', index: 2 },
    { name: 'lorem', index: 1 },
    { name: 'sit',   index: 4 },
    { name: 'dolor', index: 3 }
];
obj.sort((a, b) => a.index - b.index);

/*
0:{name: "lorem", index: 1}
1:{name: "ipsum", index: 2}
2:{name: "dolor", index: 3}
3:{name: "sit",   index: 4}
4:{name: "amet",  index: 5}
*/

Note! Array.prototype.sort is not immutable. It changes the original array and also returns the ordered array.

M'kay, but what if we have no index just a predefined ordered key list?

Let's come up with a use case for this. We have a list of dog names and we want to order them based on a predefined list of containing words.

It's a bit trickier this way but we Coding Ninjas eat things like this for breakfast, right?

This is how we do it:

// Sort dog names. Names that contain these words should go to the front.
// Exactly in this order. "dog" names first then "paw" names and so on
const preferredWords = ["dog", "paw", "bark"]; 

// this is the array we want to work on
const dogNames = [
    "Bark Twain",
    "Chewbarka",
    "Doc McDoggins",
    "Droolius Caesar",
    "Franz Fur-dinand",
    "Fyodor Dogstoevsky",
    "Hairy Paw-ter",
    "Jimmy Chew",
    "Kareem Abdul Ja-Bark",
    "Mary Puppins",
    "The Notorious D.O.G.",
    "Orville Redenbarker",
    "Ozzy Pawsborne",
    "Prince of Barkness",
    "Salvador Dogi",
    "Santa Paws",
    "Sarah Jessica Barker",
    "Sherlock Bones",
    "Winnie the Poodle",
    "Woofgang Puck"
];

// order names based on a custom function
dogNames.sort((a, b) => {
    // find out what index the current and previous array item has
    let aIdx = findLastIndex(a, preferredWords);
    let bIdx = findLastIndex(b, preferredWords);

    // non matching words have an index of -1
    // they need to go to the end
    aIdx = ~aIdx ? aIdx : Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER;
    bIdx = ~bIdx ? bIdx : Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER;

    return aIdx - bIdx;
});

/**
 * Returns the index of the last found needle in the haystack
 * Returns -1 if not found
 */
function findLastIndex(haystack, needles) {
    return needles.reduce((iMax, word, i) => ~haystack.toLowerCase().indexOf(word) ? i : iMax, -1);
}

/*
dogNames =>
[
    "Fyodor Dogstoevsky",   // "dog" names
    "Doc McDoggins",
    "Salvador Dogi",
    "Hairy Paw-ter",        // "paw" names
    "Ozzy Pawsborne",
    "Santa Paws",
    "Orville Redenbarker",  // "bark" names
    "Kareem Abdul Ja-Bark",
    "Prince of Barkness",
    "Chewbarka",
    "Bark Twain",
    "Sarah Jessica Barker",
    "Jimmy Chew",           // every other
    "Franz Fur-dinand",
    "Mary Puppins",
    "Woofgang Puck",
    "Droolius Caesar",
    "Sherlock Bones",
    "Winnie the Poodle",
    "The Notorious D.O.G."
]
*/

Om nom nom... delicious! :)

item.title: JS terminology - Temporal Dead Zone
item.description: Temporal Dead Zone - JS terminology As of ES6 two new block-scoped variable types are introduced, the let and const . These have a so‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
Temporal Dead Zone - JS terminology

As of ES6 two new block-scoped variable types are introduced, the let and const. These have a so called Temporal Dead Zone (TDZ) where the variable can't be accessed (not even with typeof) until execution reaches the declaration.

What does this mean in an example?

console.log(varLet); // ReferenceError
console.log(varConst); // ReferenceError

let varLet = 'foo';
const varConst = 'bar';

This doesn't mean that these variables are not hoisted, they are just in a period between entering scope and being declared where they cannot be accessed. They are in a TDZ.

Here's the proof:

let x = 'outer value';
(function() {
  // start TDZ for x
  console.log(x);
  let x = 'inner value'; // declaration ends TDZ for x
}());

‚Äî TEMPORAL DEAD ZONE (TDZ) DEMYSTIFIED

Where else?

Default function arguments have a TDZ too and they come with ES6 too. Arguments are evaluated left to right, and each argument is in the TDZ until it is assigned:

function foo(a = b, b) { }
foo(undefined, 1); // throws ReferenceError: b is not defined

Does var has a Temporal Dead Zone too?

Nope. Because the life cycle of var-declared variables are a bit different.

When the scope (its surrounding function) of a var variable is entered, storage space (a binding) is created for it. The variable is immediately initialized, by setting it to undefined.

‚Äî exploringjs.com

let and const variables however are remaining uninitialized and getting or setting an uninitialized variable causes a ReferenceError.

Why is there a Temporal Dead Zone?

In short: because of const. let also has TDZ so that switching between the two doesn‚Äôt change behavior.

The longer answer:

There was significant technical discussion of that topic and TDZs emerged as the best solution. An alternative argument you could make would be to eliminate const. Is there a reason you aren't making that argument?

‚Äî Performance concern with let/const - Mozilla mail

Use TDZ to your advantage and think of it as a way to catch programming errors at an early stage.

item.title: WTF JS explanation - null is not falsy
item.description: WTF JS explanation for "null is not falsy" Premise ‚Äî wtfjs.com - null is not falsy Explanation The original title says that null is not‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
WTF JS explanation for "null is not falsy"

Premise

[] == false; // true
"" == false; // true
null == false; // false, that's more like it

‚Äî wtfjs.com - null is not falsy

Explanation

The original title says that null is not falsy. I'd rather say null is not false and lets see how these Abstract Equality Comparisons are working according to the Specification.

The format of the comparison looks like this: x == y.

Now, lets look how the comparison of the first line is performed:

  • Determine that Type(x) and Type(y) are different
  • Determine Type(y) is Boolean, return the result of the comparison x == ToNumber(y). In any case if the comparison contains a Boolean value it is converted to a Number.
  • This is what we get so far: [] == 0.
  • Now, because of Type(x) is Object and Type(y) is Number, the result of the comparison is ToPrimitive(x) == y
  • An Array is an Object and the ToPrimitive function calls the objects [[DefaultValue]] internal method with a hint parameter
  • The result of ToPrimitive([]) is an empty string, and now we have the same comparison as the second line: "" == 0
  • According to the spec:

If Type(x) is String and Type(y) is Number, return the result of the comparison ToNumber(x) == y.

‚Äî Abstract Equality Comparison -- ecma-international.org

  • The result of ToNumber("") is 0, so we arrive at 0 == 0 and that's obviously true ;)

What about that ominous null == false?

This is the definition of null:

primitive value that represents the intentional absence of any object value.

‚Äî es5.github.io

According to the spec null is only equal to undefined and nothing else. This is why null is NOT equal to false. This doesn't mean that null is not falsy.

In fact null IS falsy:

A falsy value is a value that translates to false when evaluated in a Boolean context.

Examples of falsy values in JavaScript: 

if (false)
if (null)
if (undefined)
if (0)
if (NaN)
if ('')
if ("")

‚Äî es5.github.io

item.title: WTF JS explanation - null is not an object
item.description: WTF JS explanation for "null is not an object" Premise ‚Äî wtfjs.com - null is not an object Explanation The first line of the premise is a‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
WTF JS explanation for "null is not an object"

Premise

typeof null // object
null instanceof Object // false

‚Äî wtfjs.com - null is not an object

Explanation

The first line of the premise is a known "bug" in ECMAScript. typeof null should be null. Instead the spec defines that Type(null) should be object.

You know, this all came about because of rushing in early May 1995, which led to a leak of type tag representation shared by null and object types. But null means "no object", so it didn't raise hackles until it was too late to fix in Netscape 2, and after that we were loath to "fix" it and "break the web".

That argument only applies more in degree of web population now.

We have other fish to fry. This one was has been swallowed already. Let's not change typeof null for ES4 and work on more vital issues.

‚Äî Brendan Eich (Founder of Javascript)

On the other hand null can't have properties so it cannot be considered as an object. It's just a keyword representing a primitive, like true or false. Hence true instanceof Object is also false.

It could be trivial because we are explicitly creating an Object but if you say new Boolean(true) instanceof Object then it will return true.

item.title: WTF JS explanation - parseInt treachery
item.description: WTF JS explanation for "parseInt treachery" Premise ‚Äî wtfjs.com - parseInt treachery Explanation Because the second argument for radix is‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
WTF JS explanation for "parseInt treachery"

Premise

parseInt('06'); // 6
parseInt('08'); // 0

‚Äî wtfjs.com - parseInt treachery

Explanation

Because the second argument for radix is missing the parseInt function tries to guess which Base the given number has. Our example starts with 0 so it will be parsed as an octal number BUT only in browsers < ES5. As of ES5 only hexadecimal literals can have a prefix (0x or 0X).

If I try to parse an octal number with a formerly supported 0o or 0O prefix in the current browsers the result will always be 0. That's because an octal prefix is now not supported and the loop inside of parseInt breaks on the first ignored character (the o) that cannot be interpreted as an integer.

For further details on how the parseInt works see the spec for help.

item.title: WTF JS explanation - Maths fun
item.description: WTF JS explanation for "maths fun" Premise ‚Äî wtfjs.com - Maths fun Explanation Line 1 It's not the languages fault that these lines are‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
WTF JS explanation for "maths fun"

Premise

Clearly JavaScript is not the most beautiful, or intuitive, language for maths.

typeof NaN === 'number' // true
Infinity === 1/0        // true
0.1 + 0.2 === 0.3       // false

‚Äî wtfjs.com - Maths fun

Explanation

Line 1

It's not the languages fault that these lines are true. JavaScript uses the IEEE 754 technical standard for floating-point computation. This was established in 1985 to address many problems found in the diverse floating point implementations that made them difficult to use reliably and portably. Even many hardwares are using this standard.

Let's look at the first example. It says that the type of NaN (Not a Number) is number. As this might seem controversial it's also understandable. If you explicitly want to convert a variable to a number what type of output are you expecting if the variable has a string in it?

For example: var foo = "bar"; var fooToNumber = parseInt(foo);)

Well, I'd expect a number of course. However a string can not be represented with a number so we need a non-finite quantity that represents an unrepresentable value. This is what NaN stands for. Similarly Infinity is also such a value. This leads us to the next line...

Line 2

From a mathematical perspective this line is a bit of a nonsense. If 1 / 0 === Infinity then Infinity * 0 === 1 should also be true but this is not the case. However let's see an explanation about this:

Now many people like scientists and engineers do not want to be bothered with writing trap routines. So Kahan, the inventor of IEEE-754, decided that every operation should > also return a sensible default value if no trap routines exist.

They are

  • NaN for illegal values
  • signed infinities for Overflow
  • signed zeroes for Underflow
  • NaN for indeterminate results (0/0) and infinities for (x/0 x != 0)
  • normal operation result for Inexact

‚Äî Thorsten S. - Stackoverflow

Line 3

Again, this is not a JavaScript specific bug. This is true for most programming languages. Computers are working in Base 2 (binary) while the decimal representation is Base 10. When we try to write a decimal number in binary we use the format of a whole number times a power of two. Rational numbers (such as 0.1, which is 1/10) whose denominator is not a power of two cannot be exactly represented.

That's why: 0.1 + 0.2; // 0.300000004

This approximation error value is below the Number.EPSILON value.

The Number.EPSILON property represents the difference between 1 and the smallest floating point number greater than 1.

var result = Math.abs(0.2 - 0.3 + 0.1);

console.log(result);
// expected output: 2.7755575615628914e-17

console.log(result < Number.EPSILON);
// expected output: true

‚Äî Number.EPSILON

item.title: WTF JS explanation - not a number is not a not a number
item.description: WTF JS explanation for "not a number is not a not a number" Premise ‚Äî wtfjs.com - not a number is not a not a number Explanation NaN is‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
WTF JS explanation for "not a number is not a not a number"

Premise

NaN === NaN // false

‚Äî wtfjs.com - not a number is not a not a number

Explanation

NaN is not like any other primitive value. It's a result of failed type conversion instead of throwing an exception. You can't do things with it (NaN + 1 is still NaN) and can't compare it to other values. In fact, this is the only "value" that doesn't equal to any other value including itself.

There's even an if in the spec saying:

If Type(x) is Number, then
  a. If x is NaN, return false.
  b. If y is NaN, return false.

‚Äî The Strict Equality Comparison Algorithm

Note, that the Strict Equality Comparison Algorithm differs from the SameValue Algorithm used internally. While SameValue(NaN, NaN) === true, it's used only internally by the language itself. However as of the new ECMAScript 2015 version there is a polyfillable Object.is method which exposes this SameValue algorithm. This is why Object.is(NaN, NaN) === true.

In case there is a chance of comparing two NaN variables with each other, use the Object.is method. Though this works it's somewhat discouraged because NaN usually means that there is an error in the code and you should fix that instead.

item.title: Module patterns in Javascript
item.description: What are modules? The best definition I found about modules is this: A module is a reusable piece of code that encapsulates implementation‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
What are modules?

The best definition I found about modules is this:

A module is a reusable piece of code that encapsulates implementation details and exposes a public API so it can be easily loaded and used by other code.

‚Äî By Jurgen Van de Moere

  • A common Javascript design pattern
  • Small units of independent and reusable code
  • They are similar to classes in other languages, however Javascript modules export an object literal, function or a constructor.
  • Initially we didn't have any classes in Javascript so we had to come up with design-patterns that solved this shortage
  • As of ES6 (ECMAScript 2015) a class syntax is available however it primarily is a syntactical sugar over the existing prototype-based inheritance

What are the benefits?

  • singleton: modules are commonly used as singletons so only one instance exists (which is a common use case with classes too)

  • abstract code: to delegate functionality to specialised libraries so that we don't have to understand the complexity of their actual implementation

  • dependency injection:

  • It's easy to use and creates encapsulation of our code. No more changing global variables

  • It's great for services and testing/TDD

Specificity is the means by which browsers decide which CSS property values are the most relevant to an element and, therefore, will be applied.

‚Äî MDN web docs

What does this mean?

There are multiple ways to write a CSS selector and style an element on the page. Consider this simple case:

    <ul>
        <li class="list-item" id="featured-item">
            <span>Lorem ipsum</span>
        </li>
        <li class="list-item active">
            <span>Dolor sit amet</span>
        </li>
        <li class="list-item" style="color: red;">
            <span>Consectetur adipiscing elit</span>
        </li>
    </ul>

item.title: WTF JS explanation - Almost but not quite
item.description: WTF JS explanation for "Almost but not quite" Premise ‚Äî wtfjs.com - Almost but not quite Explanation JavaScript numbers are 64-bit double‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
WTF JS explanation for "Almost but not quite"

Premise

alert(111111111111111111111); // alerts 111111111111111110000

‚Äî wtfjs.com - Almost but not quite

Explanation

JavaScript numbers are 64-bit double values, which are based on the IEEE 754 Standard for Floating-Point Arithmetic. Numbers are stored in a 64 bit binary format, the default output is decimal.

This means that the maximum safe integer is 9007199254740992 (which is Math.pow(2, 53)).

All integers below this number can be represented:

Math.pow(2, 53); // 9007199254740992
Math.pow(2, 53) - 1; // 9007199254740991
Math.pow(2, 53) - 2; // 9007199254740990

Integers greater than that cannot be safely represented:

Math.pow(2, 53); // 9007199254740992
Math.pow(2, 53) + 1; // 9007199254740992
Math.pow(2, 53) + 2; // 9007199254740994

As you can see in the example above the argument of the alert is greater than the Number.Number.MAX_SAFE_INTEGER therefore can not be represented.

Compare: 
111111111111111111111

and
111111111111111110000

to
9007199254740992

item.title: WTF JS explanation - Foonanny
item.description: WTF JS explanation for "Foonanny" Premise ‚Äî wtfjs.com - Foonanny Explanation Strings can not be represented as numbers. If you think about‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
WTF JS explanation for "Foonanny"

Premise

("foo" + + "bar") === "fooNaN" // true

‚Äî wtfjs.com - Foonanny

Explanation

Strings can not be represented as numbers. If you think about it lorem ipsum is just simply not a number. Oh wait, that's exactly what we've got. Let's break down the steps:

Number("lorem ipsum"); // NaN

We can trigger an explicit toNumber coertion with the + operator:

+"lorem ipsum"; // NaN
+ "lorem ipsum"; // NaN
+          "lorem ipsum"; // NaN

You see where I'm going? :)

We can put some extra parenthesis to make things explicit:

("foo" + (+"bar")) === "fooNaN" // true

The new equation looks like this:

("foo" + NaN) === "fooNaN" // true

We have a string and a NaN value with an addition operator. According to the spec:

If Type(lprim) is String or Type(rprim) is String, then Return the String that is the result of concatenating ToString(lprim) followed by ToString(rprim)

‚Äî Spec 11.6.1

This means it's interpreted like this:

("foo" + String(NaN)) === "fooNaN" // true

String(NaN) // "NaN"

We can see why this is true:

"foo" + "NaN" === "fooNaN" // true

That's it! :)

item.title: About CSS specificity
item.description: What is specificity? Specificity is the means by which browsers decide which CSS property values are the most relevant to an element and‚Ä¶
item.dc:creator: Fil Flora
item.content:encoded:
What is specificity?

Specificity is the means by which browsers decide which CSS property values are the most relevant to an element and, therefore, will be applied.

‚Äî MDN web docs

What does this mean?

There are multiple ways to write a CSS selector and style an element on the page. Consider this simple case:

    <ul>
        <li class="list-item" id="featured-item">
            <span>Lorem ipsum</span>
        </li>
        <li class="list-item active">
            <span>Dolor sit amet</span>
        </li>
        <li class="list-item" style="color: red;">
            <span>Consectetur adipiscing elit</span>
        </li>
    </ul>

We have multiple list items with different attributes. All these attributes, tags and contexts are ways we can reach out to that element with selectors to style them. There are different types of selectors so we can style an element a million ways.

Let's say we want to color every list item blue and the featured-item should be red. We write some CSS and magically it works but why? 

    #featured-item {
        color: red;
    }
    ...
    li.list-item {
        color: blue;
    }

We wrote two selectors and both of them are setting the same elements color property. A text cannot be blue and red at the same time. That's why browsers calculate selector specificity so they can decide which property definition is more specific. Every selector type has a score. The higher the score the more specific a selector is to an element.

Basic rules when calculating specificity

  • Specificity is only applied when the same element is targeted by multiple selector declarations.
  • Directly targeted elements will always take precedence over inherited selectors no matter what specificity the inherited rule has.
  • When declarations have equal specificity, the last one in order will be applied.
  • Tree proximity ignorance: When calculating a selector score the proximity of the elements in the document tree has no effect on specificity. These selectors have all the same score: html .list-item, body .list-item, li.list-item
  • The specificity scoring system looks like this: 0,0,0,0
  • Each number is increased when a specific type of selector part is used. For example an id selectors score is 0.1.0.0, a class selectors score is 0.0.1.0, and an element selector is 0.0.0.1.
  • When we combine these selector parts the score adds up (e.g., body li.list-item has a score of 0.0.1.2 because we have used 2 element selectors and a class selectos)
  • Inline styles (almost) always overwrite any styles in external stylesheets and could be considered as the selector with the highest specificity value with 1.0.0.0. (The !important property exception will be covered later)
  • Only the form of a selector counts. The [id="featured-item"] selector is considered as an attribute selector and not an ID.
  • A class selector beats any number of element selectors. Just like an ID selector beats any number of class selector. Demo CodePen with 12 classes vs 1 ID
  • The last rule overrides any previous, conflicting rule.
  • The embedded style sheet is always closer to the element. (In case we have two selectors styling the same element with the same specificity)
  • It's a good practice to minimize the number of selectors we use to style an element and to keep the specificity value as low as possible. (It could go ugly real fast if you have to create a higher specificity selector with hacks like this: .list-item.list-item.list-item)
  • Repeated occurrences of the same simple selector are allowed and do increase specificity. (e.g., .list-item.list-item is valid and has a specificity of 0.0.2.0)

Memorize how to measure specificity:

‚ÄúStart at 0, add 1000 for style attribute, add 100 for each ID, add 10 for each attribute, class or pseudo-class, add 1 for each element name or pseudo-element. ‚Äù

Selector types that increase specificity

  • ID selectors (e.g., #featured-item) -> 0.1.0.0
  • Class selectors (e.g., .list-item), attribute selectors (e.g., [id]) and pseudo-classes (e.g. :hover, :nth-child(), :nth-last-child()) -> 0.0.1.0
  • Type selectors (e.g., li) and pseudo-elements (e.g., ::before) -> 0.0.0.1
  • Selectors declared inside of :not()
  • The most specific selector inside :matches() or :has()

Selectors that have no effect on specificity

  • Inherited values
  • Universal selector (*)
  • Combinators (+, >, ~, )
  • Negation pseudo-class itself (:not()).
  • A :something() pseudo-class

The !important exceptions

  • The !important value appended to a property value (e.g., font-size: 33px !important;) overrides even inline styles.
  • Using !important is strongly discouraged as it could produce unexpected property behavior. Most of the times it is considered a bad practice to solve a problem permanently with !important.
  • To override an !important property is only possible via another !important value within a selector with a same or higher specificity score.

  • Some rules of thumb:

    • Always look for a way to use specificity before even considering !important
    • Only use !important on page-specific CSS that overrides foreign CSS (from external libraries, like Bootstrap or normalize.css).
    • Never use !important when you're writing a plugin/mashup.
    • Never use !important on site-wide CSS.
